newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian MinFins track low US bonds, shrug off data.
newsitem.headline: Russian MinFins track low US bonds, shrug off data.

text.p: Russian MinFin bonds were unaffected by what traders said were neutral U.S. unemployment statistics but eased earlier, tracking lower U.S. Treasuries and Brady bonds on Wednesday, dealers said on Thursday.
U.S. jobless claims were unchanged at 347,000 the week ending May 3 from the previous week, the U.S. Labor Department reported on Thursday.
"There was no impact as the figures are neutral. Prices eased in the morning as U.S. Treasuries closed lower yesterday and on weaker Bradies," Avtobank dealer Ivan Kuznetsov said.
MinFins and other emerging debt are sensitive to any news which would suggest a further rise in U.S. interest rates because this would push down U.S. Treasury bond prices.
On May 20, the U.S. policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee meets and it will be closely watched for possible changes to U.S. interest rates.
Dealers said the market had found support for the most actively traded third, fourth and fifth tranches at 86.20, 61.60 and 43.60, respectively.
They said selling was seen mostly from Western players, with Russian banks trading less because of a shortened trading session ahead of the May 9 Victory Day holiday.
"Western banks were selling today as actively as they were buying before. It could be due to either profit-taking or correction after some days of rise on client interest," one dealer said.
